column1: Will legislation permitting electric utilities to recover 2018 wildfire liability debt costs by charging customers become law in California before 14 October 2019?
column6: ['Society', 'Environment', 'US Policy']
I stand corrected!
Confirmation of previous forecasts. Nothing new has occurred to change this.
It's California--one of the most corporate states in the Union.
I believe this "became law" as AB 1054 in July. https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200AB1054

I find available information about this question vague. The governor signed legislation in July, but as far as I can tell, it requires approval by a commission that looks like it won't meet until the 21st.
To little time to happen
Not going to happen in the time left.
Oct 13 is the final day of the year the Governor can sign Bills into laws, worth watching up until then.
I'm basically free riding on this one. Time appears to have effectively run out for a bill to be passed by Oct 14.
Late in updating this to 0%, no bill was up nor passed that would do this during the September session. Thus nothing can take effect prior to the deadline
Passage of time
Time is running out.
Between time elapsed and the fact that a new bill meant to address the issue doesn't do this, I'm thinking chances are slim to none at this point.
Passage of time

The utility companies will instead participate in a fund that will (allegedly) offset the costs to raising the consumer's bill. https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2019-07-25/california-utilities-agree-to-pay-10-5-billion-into-new-wildfire-fund
I found nothing today in the 16 items related to CA wildfire liability legislation that indicates any are being forwarded for Governor's signature.
Power company's cannot fail.

Originally misread the question. Not finding anything specific on 2018 liability - I've asked my state senator to identify any pending AB or SB bills that are in conference or otherwise specific to the 2018 liabilities, as well as tools for further leg. research.
I have AB 1054 and a summary of AB 111 up on the screen. They were both passed and signed into law on July 12, with both to take effect immediately. Trick question? Have I missed something?
people are still upset the power company failed to act to prevent the wildfires and I doubt it will pass before October 14

Utilities will not be allowed to recover liability, but may be able to collect other "costs" which will be used to pay debt,

The utilities are needed by everyone and the utilities have the legislative and political clout to work in their favor. It is cheaper for them to run a advertising campain for their own support once than to pay additional costs yearly without bonds for wildfire liabilities!

OH ~14 days.
Because the rate of wildfires their equipment cause will outway the losses from the fires they start.

Savior legislation is rare and PGE is judged to be the cause of the 2018 Camp Fire, making savior leg unpopular.
Yes. It makes sense. California is actually trying to do something about the Environment

Adjusting given the verbiage of AB 1054 & the analysis of the bill (I attempted to break it down in order to get a more precise answer about whether or not the wildfire fund would be applicable retroactively, but was unable to find the specific passages I wanted). Common reporting however gives the effective date as only being post-confirmation of the funds creation.

Seems less likely with recent passage of AB 1054 which creates a $10B or $21B liquidity fund (depending on which utilities opt in: SoCal Edison, SDG&E). Though this does not apply to 2018 fires, it seems less likely that California legislators would help utilities recover funds for 2018 fires from ratepayers with a rate hike after passing this legislation which appears to have staved off a looming downgrade of the utilities credit ratings.
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-wildfire-fund-gavin-newsom-20190711-story.html%3foutputType=amp

Current bill in legislature does not seem to provide payment of debt incurred in 2018. But, the fact that the legislation is moving forward to Assembly allows for the chance of a modified bill that could provide for that debt relief.
Proposed bill doesn't allow utilities to charge higher rates in order to pay for 2018 wildfires liabilities. Am I missing something?
Government, especially in California, always favors business over consumers.
Legislation has now passed the California Senate. https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-gavin-newsom-wildfire-damages-plan-20190708-story.html%3foutputType=amp
Given the short time span and little recent action. Though, it does seem necessary eventually.

The litigation against the utilitiy companies is valid. So-Cal Edison neglected its infrastructure for decades in order to produce profits for shareholders. The privately owned utilities should be bankrupted, dissolved and put under government management. But this will not happen. In the end, it looks like the taxpayers will be bailing out the corporate malfeasants.

Suspect bonds are more likely than rate increases, but it will depend upon finding that PG&E was not responsible for the fires. No government would readily allow a utility that create the problem to have their customers bail them out of it.
big business always win and passes the cost on
Likely. There is no limit to the degree that corporations can get away with murder.
Too much political sensitivity to the losses of victims to be seen supporting PGE at election time
Legislature will not act on it. They look headed in creating a liability fund rather than inverse condemnation.

(4â†“) Word from the California lawmaker discussions today show little movement on the issue of wildfire liability in either direction. Multiple avenues are still firmly on the table, but direct changes to ratepayer protections do not appear to be among them. Again likely to have another update by the end of the week on this issue.
Likely drawn out with not much legislation over summer months

Update expected tomorrow evening, at this point I'm reducing my weighting on whether or not a bill of this type may happen to the likelihood that it goes in as an October 1st effective law & not a January 1st effective law. I think it's highly unlikely that a viable bill could make it through in time unless something is proposed in the next couple of weeks, thus any announcement tomorrow by the state legislature/governor's office will sway my forecast dramatically.

Of course. Rather than taking money from the shareholders for poorly maintained power lines that caused the wild fires they screw consumers. Bad idea.
It is bondholders versus ratepayers. Rate payers vote. No one likes pge so there is no path to this becoming law.

Adjusting (7â†‘) after reviewing proposals put forward in the Strike Force's report released a couple weeks back & after reviewing the open ended phrasing of the question. Some of the proposals put forward would technically allow for utilities to recover funds from 2018 fires, though such allowance would be incidental to implementing these recommendations, not instrumental within them. AKA implementing their recommendations would allow for the possibility of fund recovery from 2018 fires by increasing rates, but would not in itself allow for utilities to immediately do so (i.e. fault-based standard).
very liberal policies in California put the onus on the customers in at risk locations
Given the consumer protection bias in the state of California, I consider it unlikely the legislation will pass
Haven't done any research on this whatsoever, but based on the question it seems like a logical outcome. Notwithstanding the tight timeframe however...
This what a non government regulated industry does as common practice.
Patern recognition

(1) I really don't understand this question. Why is there a need? Companies can already raise their prices by saying expenditures have risen by so & so. And, so, charge more. Or, just apply to whatever authority for price increase. No need for a new law. (2) California is a very progressive state. People will howl over other avenues not explored. Worse comes to worse, the state can provide some compensation. I.e., the state is in a better position to deal with the companies rather than individual customers.
The principle has already been approved, this is just another detail.
it is election year, increasing prices does not look good

A bill must be in print 30 days before moving through legislation. Chris Holden had such a bill drafted in November, but it hasnâ€™t been introduced yet because of controversy. So it only has 5.5 months, until September 14th, to be introduced in time. Yet PG&E has filed bankruptcy, and the gov called for a commission plan by April 12th, though the deadline is July 1st. Letâ€™s guess it arrives in between, mid-May, leaving 4 months to pass a bill by the deadline.
This will become law, the question is how quickly.
Not enough time
Without this CA customers might lose electricity
Sound like something a Liberal would dream up and California is full of them.

It is already in existing legislation -- This bill would increase the maximum penalty to $100,000. The bill would prohibit an electrical corporation from recovering a fine or penalty through a rate approved by the PUC, and would make related nonsubstantive changes. This bill would authorize the PUC, in an application by an electrical corporation to recover costs and expenses arising from a catastrophic wildfire, to allow cost recovery if the costs and expenses are just and reasonable, based on the PUCâ€™s consideration of the conduct of the electrical corporation and relevant information submitted into the PUCâ€™s record, including, but not limited to, information regarding specified factors. (10) Existing law prohibits an electrical corporation or gas corporation, for a period of 5 years following a safety violation causing more than $5,000,000 in ratepayer liability, as specified, from recovering from ratepayers expenses for annual compensation of an officer in excess of $1,000,000 without PUC approval. Existing law requires the electrical corporation or gas corporation seeking to pay, or seeking recovery of, annual officer compensation in excess of $1,000,000 during that 5-year period to file an application with the PUC containing specified information. Existing law requires the PUC, following a duly noticed public hearing in a proceeding to consider the application, to issue a written decision on the application. This bill would repeal the above provisions relating to excess annual compensation of utility officers. The bill would prohibit an electrical corporation or gas corporation from recovering from ratepayers any annual salary, bonus, benefits, or other consideration of any value, paid to an officer of the electrical corporation or gas corporation, and would require that compensation to instead be funded solely by shareholders of the electrical corporation or gas corporation
Californians unlikely to be sympathetic to PG&E's troubles.
Unlikely as the cost will be too high

Little tend to happen after an event has occured, as something else will be top-of-the mind for the population and politicians. I don't see the chances of this happening to be large, unless a new event will occur.

Its California! They care about their people. Their land and the eco system. They will charge because that people would not mind paying.

There are three ways to pay for natural disasters: taxpayers, ratepayers, and stockholders. You have to completely wipe out stockholders to raise anywhere near the cost of the "Camp" fire. The new utility, post bankruptcy, will need money from ratepayers or taxpayers. Sooner or later it's the ratepayers, like me, who will have to pay the costs. If it wasn't political the chances of ratepayers footing the bill would be 99.9%. Given that it is political, and the crowd forecast is 31%, I'll go as high as 51%.

So it only has 5.5 months, until September 14th, to be introduced in time. Yet PG&E has filed bankruptcy, and the gov called for a commission plan by April 12th, though the deadline is July 1st. Letâ€™s guess it arrives in between, mid-May, leaving 4 months to pass a bill by the deadline.

I can't find any indication of momentum behind this idea in the past 6 weeks. It strikes me that there are other alternatives that avoid state control. There are three possibilities: 1) this outcome 2) another resolution before October 3) no resolution before October. I think they are listed in increasing order of likelihood.

Ultimately looks like this will come down to the conclusions drawn by Gov. Newsom & the "strike team" he put together (https://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-newsom-pge-bankruptcy-plan-20190212-story.html). Given Newsom's tone toward PG&E historically (assertive but friendly) and of late (condescendingly assertive) I would lean towards very unlikely (30-40%). Given the above timeline I would drift towards the bottom of that range, so I'll settle for now at 34%
Dumb money moving higher.. If 2001-era history repeats, judicial approval of bailout (via rate payers) is probable, but unlikely to finish until early 2021.
It's the California way
How does PG&E pay for the damages otherwise? Also, Oct 14 feels a little random, do they know something we don't?
Im confident. 90% confident.
There ar no alternatives to the funding of PG&E, to get them out of bankruptcy
The politics are right for it.
Miraculous recovery in PG&E stock (PCG) says it all, the hedge fund + Sacramento fix is in.

The sums are staggering and the costs to the consumer would be massive, even spread out over a large population like California. If negligence is shown near the seats of the main fires, why should consumers pay for corporate negligence? Brown is already warning everyone that fires are 'new normal' but unless he sees a way to control energy costs, California could be priced out of some industries - and hitech industries are big power users. High voltage power lines running over wilderness areas are a core probelm which could be solved by more distributed power generation (e.g. local solar, heat pump etc) but even so, dried out forest is flammable. Where would the negligence suits go then?

PG&E is largely friendless, except for such folks as are stuck with a stake in the firm. Such folks tend not to be poor and powerless, though, at least compared to the mass of consumers. I like @mpfred6 's number at the moment.

I'm not sure this question is worded properly. The public utilities need to operate and the only source of cash is ultimately the rate payers. The real question is will the PUC force the equity holders to take a complete loss before the utilities can tap the bond markets. My answer is my weighting if whether the State will allow the shareholders of the public utilities to keep their equity while allowing them to issue bonds.
Unlikely legislation will be passed as consumers should not be held accountable for all the costs of the damages.
